questions.text: A 75-year-old bedridden patient is admitted to the hospital with pneumonia. During routine care, the nurse notices an area of redness and tissue breakdown over the patient's sacrum. The patient has been immobile for several days due to weakness. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding pressure sores?

choices.text: Pressure sores occur when external pressure exceeds capillary occlusive pressure of 30 mm Hg
Malnutrition and neurological deficits are contributing factors to pressure sore development
The most common site for pressure sores is the greater trochanter
In case of pressure sores on Malleolus, lateral is more commonly affected than medial

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The most common site for pressure sores is the greater trochanter

Explanation:
The most common site for pressure sores is Ischium.

Pressure sores

Definition
  • Tissue necrosis & ulceration due to prolonged pressure
  • Other names:
    • Bedsore
    • Decubitus ulcer
    • Trophic ulcer
    • Penetrating ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • External pressure exceeds capillary occlusive pressure (>30 mm Hg) (Option A)
  • Stoppage of perfusion leading to ischemia
  • Leads to necrosis and ulceration
  • Other contributing mechanisms:
    • Malnutrition (Option B)
    • Neurological deficit

Incidence

Mnemonic: 'Indira Gandhi Stadium Inaugurated By Home Minister Office'

  • I - Ischium (Most common site)
  • G - Greater trochanter
  • S - Sacrum
  • H - Heel
  • M - Malleolus (lateral > medial) (Option D)
  • O - Occiput

Location (Common Sites)

Generally seen in 5 percent of hospitalized patients

questions.text:
A 75-year-old bedridden patient in a long-term care facility is found to have a pressure sore on his sacral area during a routine skin assessment. Upon examination, the nurse notices a deep, crater-like wound extending through the dermis into the subcutaneous tissue. The base of the wound appears red, and there is no visible bone, tendon, or muscle.

Based on the staging system for pressure sores, how would this be classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage III

Explanation:
According to the staging system for pressure sores, a Stage III pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness skin loss involving the subcutaneous tissues but not extending to the underlying fascia, muscle, or bone.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a raised, firm, reddish-purple lesion extending beyond the margins of a surgical scar on her chest. The scar is from a surgery performed 8 months ago. The lesion is pruritic and occasionally painful. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Keloid

 

Explanation:

This clinical scenario describes a keloid scar.

 

Key features that distinguish keloids from hypertrophic scars and other conditions include:

Keloid

Hypertrophic scar (Option A)
  • Extends beyond the original wound margins
  • Continues to grow over time
  • More common in darker skin types
  • Often appears on chest, shoulders, earlobes
  • May be pruritic or painful
  • Does not regress spontaneously
  • Remains within the boundaries of the original wound
  • Develops within weeks of injury
  • May regress over time (usually within a year)
  • More common than keloids
  • Can occur in any skin type
  • May be red, raised, and firm

 

The patient's scar extending beyond the original wound margins, continuing growth after 8 months, and symptoms of pruritus and pain are all consistent with a keloid.

 

  • Hypertrophic scar (Option A) is incorrect because hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound margins.
  • Dermatofibroma (Option C) is incorrect as dermatofibromas are typically small, firm nodules that don't arise from surgical scars.
  • Malignant transformation (Option D) is incorrect as malignant transformation of scars is rare and would present differently, typically with ulceration or rapid growth.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the proliferative phase of wound healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibroblast activity and collagen production

 

Explanation:

The wound-healing process consists of four overlapping phases:

 

1. Hemostasis: Immediately after injury, platelets aggregate and form a fibrin clot to stop bleeding. (Option A)

2. Inflammatory phase: Neutrophils and macrophages infiltrate the wound, removing debris and bacteria. (Option D)

3. Proliferative phase: This phase is characterized by collagen deposition, angiogenesis (formation of new blood vessels), and granulation tissue formation. (Option B)

4. Remodeling phase: The final phase involves collagen reorganization and wound contraction. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most likely to adversely affect wound healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ionizing radiation

Explanation:

Ionizing radiation impairs wound healing by causing obliterating endarteritis and decreasing vascularity.

 

Several factors can adversely affect wound healing:

Local factors

Systemic factors
  • Infection
  • Ischemia
  • Foreign body
  • Hematoma
  • Movement
  • Mechanical stress
  • Presence of necrotic tissues
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Ionizing radiation (impairs wound healing by causing obliterating endarteritis and decreasing vascularity)
  • Immunocompromised state
  • Advancing age
  • Malnutrition
  • Vitamin A & C deficiency
  • Zinc & Iron deficiency
  • Drugs (e.g., steroids, doxorubicin)
  • Jaundice
  • Uremia
  • Malignancy

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman undergoes an elective cholecystectomy. How would you classify this surgical wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class II

 

Explanation:

Cholecystectomy will be categorized under Class II (clean-contaminated wound) as it is an operative wound involving the gastrointestinal tract under controlled conditions.

 

The surgical classification of wounds includes four categories:

1. Class I - Clean (Option A): Uninfected operative wounds without inflammation. Respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are not entered. Examples: Inguinal hernia operation, mastectomy, thyroidectomy.

2. Class II - Clean-contaminated (Option B): Operative wounds in which the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, or genitourinary tract are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Examples: Cholecystectomy, elective GI surgery.

3. Class III - Contaminated (Option C): Open, fresh accidental wounds, operations with major breaks in sterile techniques or gross spillage from the GIT, and incisions with acute, non-purulent inflammation. Examples: Appendicular perforation, gastric perforation.

4. Class IV - Dirty (Option D): Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue, wounds with clinical infection, or perforated viscera. Examples: Perforated diverticulitis, fecal peritonitis.

questions.text: All of the following measures help prevent surgical site infections except:

choices.text: Proper hand hygiene and surgical scrubbing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prolonged use of postoperative drains

 

Explanation:

Prolonged use of postoperative drains can actually increase the risk of SSIs by providing a potential route for bacterial entry.

 

Surgical site infections (SSIs) are a significant cause of postoperative morbidity. Prevention strategies include:

1. Preoperative measures: Chlorhexidine showers, proper hair removal (clipping instead of shaving), and optimizing patient factors (e.g., glycemic control).

2. Intraoperative measures: Proper hand hygiene and surgical scrubbing, appropriate skin preparation, maintaining normothermia, and proper surgical technique.

3. Antibiotic prophylaxis: Administering appropriate antibiotics within 60 minutes before incision and redosing for long procedures.

4. Postoperative care: Early removal of urinary catheters and proper wound care.

 

Several specific measures that can help prevent surgical site infections:

  • Staff should follow hand washing between patients (Option B)
  • Length of hospital stay should be kept minimum (to prevent hospital-acquired infections) (Option A)
  • Preoperative shaving should be avoided if possible to minimize minor cuts
  • Antibiotic skin preparation should be standardized
  • Bowel preparation for intra-abdominal surgery should be followed
  • Best time to give preoperative antibiotics: At the time of induction via IV route or 1 hour before surgery (Option D)
  • Attention to theater technique & discipline
  • Avoid hypothermia pre-operatively
  • Monofilament sutures should be preferred over polyfilament sutures (Increased risk of infection in polyfilament)
  • Proper apposition of the wound during suturing
  • Prevention of dead space & hematoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with a large, open wound on the lower leg that has been left to heal naturally without surgical closure. This type of healing is best described as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary intention

 

Explanation:

Wound healing can occur by different mechanisms:

 

1. Healing by primary intention or first intention (Option A): Edges of a clean wound are brought together and secured with sutures, staples, or adhesives. Minimal scarring occurs.

2. Healing by secondary intention (Option B): The wound is left open to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialization. This is common in wounds with significant tissue loss or contamination.

3. Healing by tertiary intention (delayed primary closure) (Option C & D): The wound is initially left open and then closed surgically after several days when it's clean and granulating. This is used for contaminated wounds to prevent infection.

In the given scenario, the large, open wound left to heal naturally without surgical closure is healing by secondary intention.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old diabetic patient presents with a non-healing ulcer on their heel that has persisted for 4 months despite regular dressing changes and offloading. The image showing the wound is given below.



Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Chronic wound is a wound that persists beyond 4-12 weeks from its first appearance
Delay in healing most commonly occurs due to prolonged inflammatory phase
Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage
Examples of chronic wounds include vascular ulcers, diabetic ulcers, and pressure sores

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pain is initially severe, but disappears with time due to nociceptor damage

Explanation:
Chronic wounds commonly present with sharp chronic pain which increases with time. In fact, pain is one of the factors in deciding the treatment protocol.

 

Chronic wound

Definition

Any wound which persists beyond 4-12 weeks despite conservative treatment (dressing) (Option A)

Pathophysiology
  • Wounds that fail to progress through normal stages of wound healing
  • Most commonly prolonged phase is the Inflammatory phase (Option B)
  • Formation of microbial biofilms on wound

Treatment
  • Conservative treatment- Tried first, though mostly requires aggressive treatment (surgical)
  • Surgical treatment- Debridement, control of infection and inflammation
  • Surgical treatment is done when the patient suffers from intractable pain

Examples
  • Vascular ulcers (Option D)
  • Diabetic ulcers
  • Pressure sores

questions.text:
A 35-year-old factory worker presents to the emergency department with a severe injury to his right forearm after it was caught in a machine, as shown in the picture below.



Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the injury?

choices.text: It occurs due to shearing force between tissue planes, usually between subcutaneous tissue and deep fascia or between muscle and bone.
Skin viability is assessed using Fluorescein injection under anesthesia
Characteristic Morel-Lavallée lesion can be seen due to edema of surrounding viable tissue around the wound
Treatment primarily involves a multidisciplinary approach which may require amputation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Characteristic Morel-Lavallée lesion can be seen due to edema of surrounding viable tissue around the wound

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario according to the presentation and image is indicative of Degloving Injury. Morel-Lavallée lesion, seen in degloving injury, occurs due to disruption of perforating vascular and lymphatic vessels causing hemo-lymphatic collection between the fascial planes.

Degloving Injury

Definition

Degloving injuries are serious traumatic injuries occuring due to shearing force between tissue planes, usually between subcutaneous tissue and deep fascia or between muscle and bone. (Option A)

Pathophysiology

Avulsion due to shearing force strips off the superficial tissues exposing the neurovascular bundle, muscles, tendons, and bone.

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is mainly based on clinical appearance of the wound
  • Tissue viability is assessed by injecting Fluorescein intravenously. (Option B)

Treatment

  • Wound excision and scar revision with revascularization
  • Flap coverage by skin grafting
  • Amputation may be required. (Option D)
  • Blood transfusion in heavy blood loss

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident. He has a closed fracture of the right tibia and complains of severe pain in his right lower leg. On examination, there is pain on passive stretching of the affected limb and distal sensory disturbances are noted. The emergency physician suspects compartment syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Application of a compression bandage to reduce swelling

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Measurement of compartment pressure

Explanation:

  • The next best step after suspecting compartment syndrome in the given patient, is to measure the compartment pressure by using a pressure monitor and catheter inserted into the muscle compartment.
  • If pressure is greater than 30 mm Hg then diagnosis of compartment syndrome is confirmed, warranting further measures.

 

Compartment Syndrome

Definition

• Common in the anterior compartment of the leg and in front of the forearm.

• Because of the closed compartment, pressure increases following fracture, haematoma develops which compresses over the vessel.

• Leads to blockade of vessels causing acute ischaemia of the limb presenting with severe pain, pallor, pulselessness.

Clinical Features

• Severe pain

• Pain on passive stretching of affected limb

• Distal sensory disturbances

• Absence of distal pulses (late sign)

Investigation

• Compartment pressure is measured

• Pressure monitor & catheter inserted into muscle compartment

• Diagnosis confirmed if pressure is greater than 30 mm Hg

Treatment

Fasciotomy:

• Indication: If compartment pressure is > 30 mmHg

• Clinical signs and symptoms of compartment syndrome

Procedure

• Two longitudinal incisions should be given – one on the medial and the other on the lateral side

• Incised layers are:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous fat
  • Fascia

• After incision, the muscle should be bulging through the fascia

 

Immediate fasciotomy without further investigation (Option A): While the clinical signs are suggestive, the diagnosis should be confirmed by measuring compartment pressure before proceeding to surgery.

Applying a compression bandage (Option C) could potentially worsen compartment syndrome by increasing pressure within the compartment.

While antibiotics (Option D) might be considered for an open fracture, they are not the primary management for compartment syndrome, and the scenario describes a closed fracture.

questions.text: A 65-year-old bedridden patient presents with a stage III pressure sore on the sacrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Application of hydrocolloid dressing

Explanation:

The management of pressure sores depends on the stage and severity of the wound.

For a stage III pressure sore, conservative management is typically the initial approach, with surgery reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.

 

Conservative management includes:

1. Pressure relief: Repositioning the patient every 2-3 hours

2. Wound care: Cleaning and dressing the wound

3. Nutritional support: Ensuring adequate protein and calorie intake

4. Hydrocolloid dressings: These maintain a moist environment, promote autolytic debridement, and protect the wound

 

Surgical management is considered for:

1. Stage III and IV pressure sores that fail to heal with conservative measures

2. Exposed bone, tendon, or joint

3. Undermining, tunneling, or sinus tract formation

 

Surgical options include:

Immediate surgical debridement (Option A) is incorrect as it's too aggressive for initial management.

Negative pressure wound therapy (Option C) is typically used after debridement and is not the first-line treatment.

Flap reconstruction (Option D) is a surgical option reserved for more advanced cases or when conservative measures fail.

questions.text: What is the maximum tensile strength that a mature scar can achieve compared to normal skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 70-80%

 

Explanation:

The final tensile strength of a mature scar is typically 70-80% of normal skin

Scar formation is a complex process that occurs in several stages:

 

1. Immature scar (0-3 months):

  • Red, sometimes raised and firm
  • May be painful or itchy
  • Actively producing collagen

 

2. Mature scar (3 months to 1-2 years):

  • Flat and pale
  • No pain or itching
  • Collagen remodeling continues

 

Changes from immature to mature scar:

  • Color changes from red to pale
  • Flattening of the raised scar
  • Decrease in vascularity
  • Realignment of collagen fibers

 

The maximum tensile strength of a scar is an important characteristic:

  • At 3 weeks post-injury, the scar has about 20% of normal skin strength
  • By 3 months, it reaches about 80% of normal skin strength
  • The final tensile strength of a mature scar is typically 70-80% of normal skin
